item.title: Commerce | China resumes purchases of US soybeans
item.description: This week, China purchased two shipments of soybeans from the United States, the first of the current harvest, after months of suspension due to tariffs, Bloomberg reported yesterday, on the eve of the meeting between Xi Jinping and Donald Trump. Sources cited by the agency indicated that the shipments have already been reserved for future dates and could be part of the “preliminary agreement” signed by Beijing and Washington last week, in Kuala Lumpur, in preparation for the high-level meeting scheduled for this Thursday, in South Korea. The acquisition could mark the resumption of soybean trade flows between the two countries, within the framework of a broader understanding between the two leaders, which includes the reversal of tariffs and restrictions imposed in recent months. On Sunday, the US Treasury Secretary and head of the negotiating team, Scott Bessent, anticipated a strong return of Chinese purchases, guaranteeing that US farmers would be “extremely satisfied” with the terms of the agreement. Since Donald Trump reactivated the trade war with the imposition of tariffs in April, China has used soybeans as an instrument of pressure. Despite Trump's calls “to quadruple” orders, China diversified suppliers, increasing imports from Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay, investing in domestic production and even reducing the use of soybeans in livestock farming, according to consultancy Trivium. The same consultant warned that Chinese leaders “have no interest” in returning to depend on the US for their food security and ruled out a “structural restart” of bilateral soybean trade. This month, state television CCTV indicated that the US could lose up to 16 million tonnes in exports to China if orders were not resumed by mid-November. “Losing China means losing half the market”, he pointed out.

item.title: Government | Wong Sio Chak visited public services
item.description: Having recently taken office as Secretary for Administration and Justice, Wong Sio Chak recently visited several public services under his authority, in order to find out how they work. Since October 16th, when he took office, he has visited the Directorate of Justice Affairs Services (DSAJ), the Institute for Municipal Affairs (IAM), the Directorate of Administration and Public Service Services (SAFP) and the Official Press (IO), “having exchanged opinions with management and leadership staff and frontline workers”, highlights an official note. In the case of DSAJ, the visit took place on the 21st, with the secretary “taking note of the status of the work due to the merger of DSAJ with IO”, which will be formalized from this Friday. Another visit took place on Monday afternoon, with the government official, in the company of SAFP director Leong Weng In, and other leaders, visiting “the work offices of that service and meeting with management and leadership staff, to learn more about the work to promote Public Administration reform, matters relating to voter registration and public service on the front line of the Public Information Center”, among other tasks. Wong Sio Chak left several notes on these visits, namely “the strengthening of unity and cooperation” between workers and the promotion of “horizontal and positive communication, in order to unite the team’s synergy”, and should also focus on “the reformist and innovative spirit and assuming its responsibilities”.

item.title: PJ | Indicted for kidnapping and rape of lover
item.description: The Judiciary Police (PJ) announced the arrest of a 34-year-old man on suspicion of kidnapping, rape and serious harm to the physical integrity of his lover. The case took place in a local hotel, after the two began an extramarital relationship last year. According to the PJ's version, the man and woman are from the interior, where they met and began a romantic relationship. However, the most recent meeting in Macau ended with the alleged commission of several crimes. After a meeting in a restaurant on Saturday morning, the woman was blackmailed into going to the man's hotel room in Macau. If she refused, the lover threatened to reveal the relationship to her husband and his entire family. The woman eventually gave in, but when she arrived at the hotel room she was raped and kidnapped for at least an hour. After the first attack, the woman contacted her sister to ask for help and ended up being attacked, with an ashtray on her head, in addition to being strangled with a cell phone charger cable. Given his injuries, the man allowed the victim to contact his sister, who in turn alerted the police. The suspect ended up being detained by the authorities, and when questioned by the authorities he asserted his right to silence.

item.title: FRC | Debate on the “China-Brazil Puzzle” and the place of the Macao SAR
item.description: The Rui Cunha Foundation (FRC) presents today, starting at 6:30 pm, another debate session integrated into the “Wheel of Ideas” cycle, with the theme “The China-Brazil Puzzle: Positioning Macau’s Strategic Piece”. According to a note from the FRC, the aim of this session is “to bring together key voices to address a crucial question: how can Macau’s unique ecosystem be harnessed to facilitate, reduce risk, and add tangible value to this vital economic corridor”. Co-organized by FRC and Well Link Bank Macau, the conversation will feature four guests, namely Yuri Ribeiro, founder and CEO of “Valor da China”, a consultancy and market intelligence company exclusively dedicated to Brazil-China relations, cultural understanding and international business development, based in Guangzhou. Another guest is Alexandre Lobo, vice-rector and professor at the University of São José in Macau, presented as a “Brazilian leader in innovation, with 20 years of global experience, and who combines deep knowledge in artificial intelligence and data science, with the passion for leading transformative projects”. O leque de convidados completa-se com Felipe Ribeiro de Assis, advogado associado da PK Advogados, São Paulo, com um escritório full-service sediado no Brasil, onde coordena o “Chinese Desk”, e ainda Rodrigo Barbosa, co-fundador e director comercial da “Modular Park Brasil”, a representante exclusiva da Mussini no Brasil, especializada em construção metálica. The moderator will be José Paulo Esperança, professor and director of international partnerships at the Faculty of Management of the City University of Macau. Former Dean of ISCTE Business School and Pro-Rector for International Relations and Entrepreneurship at ISCTE-IUL, Portugal, he holds a PhD in Economics from the European University Institute. He was also vice-president of the Foundation for Science and Technology between 2019 and 2022. Challenges and opportunities Today's conversation addresses the current global panorama, where, in the “world of geopolitical and economic realignment, the China-Brazil relationship presents unprecedented opportunities and complex challenges”. Therefore, “in this new scenario, Macau’s role needs to be re-examined and redefined”, he argues. In this round table, the aim is to “translate this dialogue into action, identifying real obstacles and mapping practical paths for the integration of services in Macau, transforming its latent potential into a concrete competitive advantage”, it is said.

item.title: Elections | Portuguese MP filed case against Rita Santos
item.description: The information about the shelving of the investigation for electoral interference in the 2024 Legislatures in Portugal was provided by Canal Macau, which quotes Rita Santos herself. HM confirmed, however, the filing with the Public Ministry in Portugal The Public Ministry (MP) will have archived the investigation targeting Rita Santos, related to the 2024 Legislative Elections in Portugal. The complaint came from some members of the Socialist Party (PS) in Macau, based on suspicions about electoral interference by the Portuguese Communities councilor. HM confirmed, however, the filing of the case with the MP. According to Canal Macau, which cites Rita Santos, the investigation by the Portuguese MP was archived and the order containing the decision stated that “no evidence of irregularities was found” in the conduct of the target. The order to close an investigation is issued when evidence is collected that no crime has occurred, or even if there has been a crime that was not committed by the subject of the investigation. The MP also orders the investigation to be closed if it has not been possible to obtain sufficient evidence to verify the crime or who was the perpetrator. It was in March 2024 that information emerged that Rita Santos and the Macau Public Service Workers Association (ATFPM) were being investigated in Portugal. At the time, Portugal's National Elections Commission (CNE) revealed that it would forward complaints received about interference in Macau to the MP. The complainants accused Rita Santos and ATFPM of having influenced voters to vote for the Democratic Alliance, the coalition that in 2024 was made up of the Social Democratic Party, CDS – Popular Party and Popular Monarchic Party and which won these elections with 28.83 percent of the votes. Suspended mandate and local cooperation Despite claiming to have been exonerated, the case had an impact on Rita Santos' political activity. At the beginning of October 2024, the advisor to the Portuguese Communities chose to suspend her mandate, with the newspaper Plataforma stating that the suspension was intended to avoid notification of the ongoing electoral fraud investigation. In turn, Rita Santos justified the suspension with the desire to dedicate herself to the elections for the Chief Executive in Macau, which took place on October 13, 2024, and the elections for the Legislative Assembly, which took place on September 14 of this year. Until June of this year, ATFPM leaders, such as José Pereira Coutinho, guaranteed that Rita Santos would join the list competing with the legislative ones for the Legislative Assembly. However, in June, Rita Santos was left out. The Macanese justified her absence with the fact that she wanted to dedicate more time to her family. However, the retreat came just a few days after the Macau Public Prosecutor's Office announced that Rita Santos had been questioned in the Macao SAR, due to a request for cooperation from the Portuguese authorities in the face of suspected irregularities during the elections.

item.title: Housing | Carlotta Bruni regrets lack of creativity in Zone A
item.description: Architect Carlotta Bruni regrets that the public housing being built in Zone A of the New Landfills is not very creative. “What we see being built in Zone A are very repetitive projects, and this is a problem that has always existed in Macau.” Bruni speaks today about public housing at Casa Garden at another Docomomo Macau conference Taking place today at Casa Garden, starting at 6:45 pm, is the conference “The advent of collective housing in the 20th century”, with architect Carlotta Bruni, an event promoted by the Docomomo Macau association. At the Fundação Oriente headquarters in Macau, the topic of public housing and its urban functions will therefore be discussed. To HM, Carlotta Bruni regrets that the projects being built in Zone A of the New Landfills do not have the desired creativity. Asked whether Macau is building too much public housing, the architect said “not too much, but we are building it poorly”. "It's the evil, the ugly in those buildings. It's a co-responsibility of whoever designed them and whoever commissioned them", he said, regretting that Macau had lost an opportunity to innovate in this area. "The criticism I can make is the way these projects are developed. What we see now being built in Zone A are very repetitive projects, and the issue of having a repetitive project is a problem that has always existed in Macau. The fact that no one cares about having an ugly city", he highlighted. For Carlotta Bruni, this ugliness aspect of housing “is something that is quite disturbing”, because “we, architects, have a mission in the world to make beautiful things, in addition to making practical, functional things that are cheap and all that”. “When looking at Zone A, currently, I honestly have to say that there was a bit of a mistake there,” he added. “The two examples that I will discuss at the conference [Fai Chi Kei project and B10 building in Zone A] are a bit of a draw to the fact that social housing can be created in another way, with the same entities, but with more functions than the minimum indispensable.” Living in a box In today's talk, Carlotta Bruni “questions the spatial consequences of Macau's rapid urban densification, where the prioritization of gross built area led to the erosion of community space”, highlights a note about the conference. In this way, the architect will “explore how architectural design can recover public and semi-public environments through the strategic placement of volumes, layered typologies and pedestrian connectivity”, highlighting “alternative spatial models that resist conventional categorization, such as open courtyards, narrow squares and elevated public areas, offering new structures for collective engagement in high-density contexts”. Founder and director of the LBA Arquitectura & Planeamento studio, Bruni will tackle some of the team's projects, namely the public housing development in Fai Chi Kei, now demolished. "Then we proposed public areas on all floors, because in Macau it is often forgotten that, when building a 30-story building, a certain detachment from the street is created. People feel that, when they leave the street, it is no longer part of their daily experience." Carlotta Bruni regrets “the way social housing is designed in Macau, certainly with legal minimums in terms of space”. "We are designing very small apartments that then have no place where people can have a little more life. In the Fai Chi Kei building, there was, on every two floors, a very large space, with double height, so people could be outside, sit, do some exercise, for the children to meet up", he said. The Fai Chi Kei social housing neighborhood was designed by Manuel Vicente in 1977 and completed in 1981. Demolition took place in 2010. The LBA Architect & Planning studio designed the B10 social housing building in Zone A, whose construction has already been completed. There, too, the option was to create “a series of hanging gardens, with a varied location throughout the building”, creating “specific situations for each floor”, in order to build “small communities”. The official also defended to HM that there is “a certain lack of planning” in the context of the Greater Bay Area, or at least “planning requirements”. “It is up to architects to worry about creating buildings with more interesting urban interfaces, we have to make an effort to create a more dynamic and interesting city”, he pointed out.

item.title: HK / Elections | John Lee praises Macau model and promises to follow it
item.description: The Chief Executive of the neighboring region confirmed that he sent representatives to Macau to learn from the experience of the September Legislatures. John Lee also confirmed that he sent letters to civil servants indicating that voting is a proof of loyalty to the Basic Law and the HKSAR The Chief Executive of Hong Kong promised to follow the Macau model in the next elections for the Legislative Council. John Lee praised the measures in Macau, where public servants were warned that abstention in Legislatures could be understood as a lack of patriotism, and some heads of Public Administration departments prepared questionnaires about their subordinates' voting intentions. “I have already asked all public services to take all possible measures so that employees who need to work on voting day can travel to the polling stations in a convenient way,” said the leader of the Hong Kong Government. Like Sam Hou Fai, John Lee admitted that he also sent a letter to civil servants indicating that participation in the elections is taken as proof of loyalty to the Basic Law and the HKSAR. Unlike what happened in Macau, at first, John Lee's letter was publicly released. In the letter, the Chief Executive indicates that public servants need to be an example of civic responsibility, which they should do when voting. However, John Lee did not clarify, similar to what happened in Macau, whether he will penalize public servants who choose not to go to the polls. Messages to companies The leader of the Hong Kong Government also publicly acknowledged that as a way of preparing the Legislatures, several representatives of his Government were in Macau, where they met with local government officials, to learn about the model. John Lee gave a very positive assessment of this exchange, which he explained by considering that the elections in the Macao SAR were “carried out successfully”. However, the HKSAR Government's efforts do not stop at just mobilizing public servants. As happened in Macau, where some concessionaires and state-owned companies questioned workers about their intention to vote and arranged transport, in Hong Kong it is intended that private companies will also mobilize workers. “I also appeal to all private and public entities, organizations and companies to encourage their employees to vote, with appropriate measures”, can be read in the letter made public. Despite this plan, the Chief Executive of Hong Kong did not set a target for voter participation. "We don't have any rigid indicators, but we will do our best. That's our indicator", said John Lee. In the Macau Legislature, the participation rate was 53.35 percent, the third lowest since the transition of sovereignty.

item.title: Labor Rights | Leong Pou U debuts with orders
item.description: Deputy Leong Pou U made his debut in the Chamber calling on the Executive to update several labor rights, which have not undergone any changes for more than 30 years. “In reality, Macau's labor standards are always behind those of neighboring countries and regions, despite having a socioeconomic development similar to that of Macau, [...] and some labor standards have not been updated for decades”, began by stating the deputy linked to the Operários. “For example, working hours and annual holidays have not been changed since 1984, that is, 41 years; mandatory holidays have not been adjusted for 36 years, since 1989”, he pointed out. Based on these data, the deputy elected indirectly called on the Executive to move forward as quickly as possible with the “systematic review and improvement of labor laws and regulations, taking into account the real situation and the development trend of the Macau labor market”. Despite this request, Leong Pou U defended the need for a consensus between employers and workers to implement changes, which rarely happens, even within the Permanent Council for Social Concertation (CPCS).

item.title: AL | Leaders of work committees defined
item.description: José Chui Sai Peng will assume the presidency of the Rules and Mandates Committee, one of the most important committees. The Portuguese José Pereira Coutinho is the most experienced and oldest deputy and was the “king of votes” in direct suffrage, but he was not chosen for any leadership position On Tuesday, deputies chose the compositions and presidencies of the Legislative Assembly's working committees. Legislator and businessman José Chui Sai Peng will assume the presidency of the Rules and Mandates Committee, which is particularly important as it has the power to suggest changes to the legislative body's operating rules. For the cousin of the former Chief Executive, Fernando Chui Sai On, the presidency of a committee is nothing new, given that in the previous Legislature he led the Monitoring Committee for Public Land and Concessions Affairs. In relation to the secretary of the Rules and Mandates Committee, the choice of deputies fell on the lawyer and academic Iau Teng Pio. With regard to the permanent work committees, the 1st Committee will be led by Wong Kit Cheng, a nurse by training and Women's deputy. The secretary will be Nick Lei Leong Wong. Wong also has experience in leading committee work, as in the previous Legislature he led the Monitoring Committee for Public Finance Matters. In the 2nd Commission, the presidency was handed over to Ip Sio Kai, vice-president of the Bank of China (Macau), while the vice-presidency went to Lam Lon Wai, from the Workers' Party. In the 3rd Commission, the person chosen for president was Leong Sun Iok, also a Workers' deputy, while the secretary will be Leong Hong Sai, linked to the Residents. Lots of follow-up As for the monitoring committees, they also underwent several changes. In the Monitoring Committee for Land Affairs and Public Concessions, the presidency was attributed to Ella Lei Cheng I. In the previous Legislature, the Workers' deputy was the president of the 1st Permanent Committee. The secretary will be Joey Lao Chi Ngai, returned to the hemicycle, after being passed over as a legislator appointed by the Chief Executive by Ho Iat Seng. In the Monitoring Committee for Public Finance Affairs, Song Pek Kei will assume the presidency, while Ngan Iek Hang will serve as vice president. Finally, at the level of the Monitoring Committee for Public Administration Affairs, businessman Ma Chi Seng will be responsible for the presidency, with Kou Kam Fai as secretary. The presidency of the Administrative Council of the Legislative Assembly, which deals with matters such as the hemicycle's budget, was handed over to Ângela Leong On Kei. The committees' choices also confirm that José Pereira Coutinho was excluded from any leadership position despite being the most experienced deputy in the hemicycle, the oldest and also the one who was the “king of votes” in direct suffrage.

item.title: Netflix premieres adaptation of “The Son of a Thousand Men” in November
item.description: The adaptation of the novel “The Son of a Thousand Men”, by Valter Hugo Mãe, by Brazilian director Daniel Rezende, which was shown on Monday at the International Film Festival in São Paulo, will premiere on Netflix on November 19th. According to Porto Editora, which published the novel “O Filho de Mil Homens”, the release date of the feature film was advanced by the streaming platform. The film had its official screening this Monday, at the 49th International Film Festival in São Paulo, Brazil, one of the main cinematographic events in Latin America. Starring Rodrigo Santoro, the film tells the story of Crisóstomo, a fisherman who finds a new meaning in life when he takes in Camilo (Miguel Martines), a young orphan. The relationship between them triggers a reflection on love, acceptance and the bonds that define the concept of family. Filmed in Búzios and Chapada Diamantina, the film is a co-production between Biônica Filmes and Barry Company, which focuses on a delicate and symbolic visual approach, highlights the publisher. According to Netflix, it is “a fable about loneliness, love and acceptance”, which translates the emotional strength of Valter Hugo Mãe's writing into film. The cast also includes Rebeca Jamir, Johnny Massaro, Miguel Martines, Juliana Caldas, Grace Passô, Inez Viana, Lívia Silva, Antonio Haddad and Tuna Dwek. The São Paulo film festival also showed, in its world premiere, on October 25th, the biographical documentary “De Lugar Não”, by Portuguese director Miguel Gonçalves Mendes, about Valter Hugo Mãe and his creative process, which should arrive in Portuguese cinemas in 2026. “Retrato intimista” The work paints an intimate portrait of Valter Hugo Mãe, following the writer over seven years, as he wrote the novel “A Dehumanização”, between trips to Iceland, Brazil, Portugal, Colombia and Macau, according to information from the Portuguese consulate in São Paulo. The documentary, a visual meditation on loneliness, loss and belonging, features the participation of cartoonist Laerte Coutinho and Icelandic composer Hilmar Örn Hilmarsson, mentor of bands such as Sigur Ros and Bjork, according to the exhibition's official page. The film “From nowhere” is part of the “The Meaning of Life” project, on which director Miguel Gonçalves Mendes has been working for more than a decade — a set of nine feature films, in a kaleidoscope of contemporary figures.

item.title: Technology | Beijing launches plan to accelerate self-sufficiency
item.description: The Chinese Communist Party called for a national mobilization to achieve “decisive” advances in semiconductors and key technologies, on the eve of the meeting between the country's President and his North American counterpart in South Korea. The initiative comes at a time of renewed commercial tension with the United States, marked by the increasing use of technological controls and restrictions on access to strategic materials. In the text published by the PCC, which details the priorities for the 2026-2030 five-year plan, the party calls for “extraordinary measures” to achieve technological self-sufficiency in key areas. The official version of Chinese President Xi Jinping's speech on the plan, released yesterday by the official Xinhua news agency, highlights the need to “accelerate high-level scientific and technological self-sufficiency”. “The proposals must promote original innovation and ensure that China firmly maintains control of its growth trajectory”, stated the Chinese President, recognizing the challenges of an “increasingly adverse external environment”. The document will serve as the basis for the preparation of the official plan by the State Council (Executive), the final version of which should be approved in March 2026. In addition to the focus on innovation, the plan proposes greater investment in “human capital”, including birth subsidies, expansion of free education, reinforcement of pensions and insurance and increased rural income. Xi stated that these measures must be “integrated with investment in infrastructure”, to stimulate domestic consumption, a long-standing goal given the dependence on public investment and exports. Among the new priority sectors are quantum computing, unmanned aerial vehicles ('drones'), biotechnology, hydrogen and fusion energy, humanoid robots with artificial intelligence, brain-machine interfaces and 6G mobile networks. The use of artificial intelligence across industries is equally highlighted as a priority for the next five years.

item.title: HK | Smuggling case worth 200 million dollars discovered
item.description: Shark fins, cigars, cell phones, pharmaceutical products and even donkey skin. These are the products discovered in two more smuggling cases discovered by the Hong Kong Customs Service (SA) on the 3rd and 7th of this month. According to a statement from this organization, the value of the goods is around 200 million US dollars, with two ships involved, one of them destined for river trade. This ship was destined for Macau and was caught by the authorities on October 3rd. Five containers destined for Taiwan were also inspected and were declared to be transporting frozen food. On October 7, the SA in Hong Kong realized that 150 tons of donkey skin were circulating here and not the declared food. The same statement indicates that the investigation continues and that “the possibility of arrests is not excluded”. Under Hong Kong's Import and Export Law, anyone found guilty of importing or exporting undeclared cargo is subject to a maximum fine of US$2 million and a seven-year prison sentence upon conviction. Seven cases last week Taking into account the holding of the National Games starting next month, the Customs Service (SA) wants to show service and admitted to having reinforced inspection efforts at the Portas do Cerco Border Post. As a result of these efforts, seven cases of smuggling were recorded between 21 and 25 October. According to a statement from the SA of Macau, within the scope of the seven cases, customs agents found a total of 120 old cell phones, often used to circumvent internet access limitations, 85 pieces of electronic products and 1344 grams of cigar. The smugglers involved residents of Macau and the Interior, aged between 38 and 64 years old. Those involved were fined, the SA announced, under the provisions of the foreign trade law.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Yelu Abaoji (872-926), the head of the nomadic Khitan people, a word sinised as Qidan, contrary to tradition, decided to establish in his vast territory in 916 a dynasty in the style of the disintegrated Tang dynasty (618-907) and all the others that preceded it, with the succession of the maximum leader becoming hereditary and not a choice by a tribal council. He even went so far as, once again going against nomadic tradition, to build a «Supreme capital», Shangjing, Linhuangfu, designed in a grid pattern with streets aligned in the style of Chang’an, the capital of the Tang. And although it was the tribal military who made the decisions, Han civilians were chosen for state administration. He called this State Da Qidan and was posthumously given the title of Taizu Tian Huangdi, “Heavenly Emperor Taizu”. His successor would change the name of the dynasty to Liao and despite subsequent setbacks, this would be the name that would prevail. Abaoji had a son, Yelu Bei (899-937), whom he named Crown Prince and gave the title Renhuang Wang, «Imperial King of Men», handing him over the governance of the kingdom of Dongdan. And when the time for succession arrived, Yelu Bei naturally expected to inherit his father's title, but his mother, the ruthless Empress Dowager Shulu Ping (879-953), had other plans and with cold blood and cunning made the succession fall to another of her sons. What was improbable followed in Yelu Bei's life would be remembered years later by the poet, calligrapher and painter of the Yuan dynasty, Zhu Derun (1294-1365). Next to the figure of a horseman on a swift ride in the Deer Hunt on a horizontal scroll that was attributed to Yelu Bei (ink and color on paper, 24.6 x 79.9 cm, in the Metmuseum) he wrote: «To escape the persecution of Yelu Deguang (r. as Liao Taizong, 927-947) he crossed the sea and arrived at Dengzhou (in Shandong) and there he performed allegiance to Emperor Mingzong (r.925-933) of the Late Tang (923-936) and in return he was granted the name Li and the commandership of Huaihai.” Li Zanhua would therefore be the name that Yelu Bei would use from then on. A name – Li – of enormous prestige because this was the name of the ruling family during the Tang dynasty, offered by Emperor Xianzong (r.805-820) to the founders of that second of the Five Dynasties period as a reward for their loyalty and which they carried, like the name Tang, with pride. Li Zanhua, wrote Zhu Derun, “used to take paintings and books with him when he traveled. He liked to paint knights with bows, on hunts or excursions. His clothes and accessories followed the rustic conventions of the barbarians because that was what he was used to and felt comfortable with. The way he used the brush was soft and fine while the dynamism of the men and horses corresponds to the spirit of the 8th century Tang. A painting that deserves to be appreciated.”

item.title: Today Macau
item.description: This week, China purchased two shipments of soybeans from the United States, the first of the current harvest, after months of suspension due to tariffs, Bloomberg reported yesterday, on the eve of the meeting between Xi Jinping and Donald Trump. Sources cited by the agency indicated that the shipments have already been reserved for future dates and could be part of the “preliminary agreement” signed by Beijing and Washington last week, in Kuala Lumpur, in preparation for the high-level meeting scheduled for this Thursday, in South Korea. The acquisition could mark the resumption of soybean trade flows between the two countries, within the framework of a broader understanding between the two leaders, which includes the reversal of tariffs and restrictions imposed in recent months. On Sunday, the US Treasury Secretary and head of the negotiating team, Scott Bessent, anticipated a strong return of Chinese purchases, guaranteeing that US farmers would be “extremely satisfied” with the terms of the agreement. Since Donald Trump reactivated the trade war with the imposition of tariffs in April, China has used soybeans as an instrument of pressure. Despite Trump's calls “to quadruple” orders, China diversified suppliers, increasing imports from Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay, investing in domestic production and even reducing the use of soybeans in livestock farming, according to consultancy Trivium. The same consultant warned that Chinese leaders “have no interest” in returning to depend on the US for their food security and ruled out a “structural restart” of bilateral soybean trade. This month, state television CCTV indicated that the US could lose up to 16 million tonnes in exports to China if orders were not resumed by mid-November. “Losing China means losing half the market”, he pointed out.
